source: FDA Robotic Surgery Guidance + ISO 13482 + IEC 80601-2-77

degrees_of_freedom.definition: Number of independent motion parameters; more DoF enables complex maneuvers in confined spaces
degrees_of_freedom.typical_values: Robotic arms: 6-7 DoF (3 translation + 3-4 rotation); Endoscopic instruments: 7+ DoF (wrist articulation)
degrees_of_freedom.clinical_significance: ≥7 DoF provides redundancy for obstacle avoidance and ergonomic positioning

workspace.definition: 3D volume within which robot end-effector can position and orient surgical tool
workspace.measurement: CAD analysis or physical testing; document as sphere radius or cuboid dimensions
workspace.typical_values: Orthopedic robots: 300-500 mm radius; Laparoscopic robots: docked at patient, workspace defined by trocar positions
workspace.regulatory_testing: Verify workspace encompasses target anatomy (e.g., hip joint, prostate) from typical docking positions

positioning_accuracy.definition: Accuracy = deviation from commanded position; Repeatability = standard deviation returning to same position
positioning_accuracy.test_method: Measure end-effector position with coordinate measuring machine (CMM) or optical tracker; ASTM F2554
positioning_accuracy.typical_values: Orthopedic: <0.5 mm translational, <0.5° angular accuracy; Laparoscopic: <1 mm tip positioning
positioning_accuracy.clinical_significance: High accuracy critical for implant alignment (±2° cup placement affects THA outcomes) and tumor margin resection

haptic_feedback.definition: Kinesthetic force feedback and/or tactile vibration feedback to surgeon console from instrument-tissue interaction
haptic_feedback.measurement: Force resolution (Newtons), range (0-10 N typical for laparoscopy), update rate (≥1000 Hz for stability)
haptic_feedback.clinical_significance: Lacking in many systems (da Vinci); suture tensioning and tissue handling rely on visual cues; may reduce tissue trauma if present
haptic_feedback.regulatory_testing: Validate force display accuracy; assess user ability to discriminate force levels in human factors study

latency.definition: Time delay from surgeon master controller motion to slave instrument motion; includes signal processing, communication, actuator response
latency.acceptance_criteria: <100 ms for stable teleoperation; <50 ms optimal for complex tasks; >200 ms causes instability and surgeon discomfort
latency.test_method: High-speed camera recording master and slave motion; measure time offset; assess at various network loads if applicable
latency.clinical_significance: Excessive latency impairs surgeon performance, increases procedure time, and may cause overshoot injuries

collision_detection.definition: Real-time monitoring for unintended contact between robot and patient/operating room objects; may use force/torque sensors or virtual boundaries
collision_detection.implementation: Joint torque monitoring (detect unexpected resistance), proximity sensors, virtual workspace boundaries (software limits)
collision_detection.response: Stop motion (hard stop <10 ms), retract, or alert operator depending on severity
collision_detection.regulatory_testing: Simulate collisions with patient surrogate and OR equipment; verify detection sensitivity and response time

emergency_stop.definition: Immediate cessation of all robot motion via dedicated button(s) accessible to all team members; IEC 60601-1 Clause 15.4.4
emergency_stop.requirements: Hard-wired circuit (not software-controlled); Category 0 stop per ISO 13850 (immediate power removal); red mushroom-head button; multiple locations
emergency_stop.test_method: Activate E-stop during motion; verify all axes stop within specified time (<500 ms) and distance (<5 mm at end-effector)
emergency_stop.clinical_significance: Last-resort safety measure for runaway robot, patient emergency (cardiac arrest), or fire

redundant_safety.definition: Dual-channel monitoring of safety-critical functions; independent processors verify commanded motion within safe limits
redundant_safety.implementation: Two CPUs compare position commands; disagreement >threshold triggers safe state; watchdog timers detect processor faults
redundant_safety.standard: IEC 62304 Class C software (highest safety classification); IEC 61508 SIL 2-3 for hardware
redundant_safety.clinical_significance: Prevents single-point software/hardware failures from causing unintended motion

registration.definition: Spatial alignment of preoperative/intraoperative imaging to patient anatomy for navigation; establishes coordinate transformation
registration.methods: Fiducial markers (bone screws, skin markers), anatomical landmarks (bony prominences), surface matching (laser scan or stylus points)
registration.accuracy_metrics: Target Registration Error (TRE) and Fiducial Registration Error (FRE); TRE <2 mm for spine surgery, <1 mm for neurosurgery
registration.validation: Touch known anatomical points post-registration; measure deviation; FRE <1 mm typical acceptance

intraoperative_imaging.definition: Real-time imaging (fluoroscopy, CT, MRI, ultrasound) integrated with robot coordinate system for dynamic guidance
intraoperative_imaging.modalities: Fluoroscopy (2D X-ray), cone-beam CT (3D intraop), ultrasound (soft tissue), optical coherence tomography (OCT)
intraoperative_imaging.regulatory_considerations: IEC 60601-2-54 (X-ray); radiation dose to patient and staff; image quality sufficient for surgical decisions
intraoperative_imaging.clinical_use: Verify implant position, assess anatomical changes from preop imaging, guide instrument to target

optical_tracking.definition: Camera-based system tracking reflective markers on instruments and patient for real-time position measurement
optical_tracking.specifications: Accuracy <0.3 mm RMS; Update rate ≥20 Hz; Working volume 1-2 m³; Line-of-sight required
optical_tracking.marker_arrays: Dynamic reference frame (DRF) on patient for registration; tracked instruments with unique marker geometry
optical_tracking.limitations: Line-of-sight obstructions, OR lighting interference, marker occlusion by surgical drapes

master_controller.definition: Hand controllers at surgeon console that command slave instrument motion; may be gimbaled handles or finger-controlled
master_controller.ergonomics: Adjustable height, arm rests to reduce fatigue; neutral wrist position; clutching function to reposition hands without moving instruments

motion_scaling.definition: Ratio of master motion to slave motion (e.g., 3:1 scaling = 3 cm hand motion → 1 cm instrument tip motion)
motion_scaling.typical_values: 1:1 to 5:1 scaling; surgeon selectable; higher scaling for fine dissection
motion_scaling.tremor_filtering: High-pass filter removes physiologic tremor (5-12 Hz); improves precision for microsurgery

stereo_visualization.definition: Dual-camera endoscope with separate left/right eye video channels displayed on surgeon console, providing depth perception
stereo_visualization.technical_specs: 1080p or 4K resolution per eye; 60 fps; 10-15x magnification; inter-pupillary distance (IPD) adjustment 50-75 mm
stereo_visualization.clinical_advantage: Superior depth perception vs. 2D laparoscopy; reduces suturing errors and tissue trauma
stereo_visualization.validation: Assess stereoacuity (arc seconds); usability testing for depth perception tasks (peg transfer, suturing)

foot_pedals.definition: Foot-operated switches for camera control, energy activation (cautery), clutch engagement, instrument swap
foot_pedals.ergonomic_design: ≥5 pedals; distinct shapes/positions for tactile identification; low activation force (<5 N); prevent accidental activation
foot_pedals.human_factors: Use errors common (wrong pedal); testing per IEC 62366-1; color-coding and training reduce errors

docking.definition: Positioning robotic arms and attaching to patient port sites (trocars); critical setup step affecting workspace
docking.docking_time: 5-15 minutes typical for experienced team; learning curve 20-50 cases for proficiency
docking.considerations: Avoid arm collisions (minimum 15 cm separation); optimize for target anatomy access; fixed vs. mobile patient carts
docking.validation: Measure docking time and collision rate in human factors study; assess across range of patient sizes/positions

instrument_exchange.definition: Removing and replacing robotic instruments intraoperatively; requires assistant at bedside or automated instrument changers
instrument_exchange.time_penalty: Manual exchange: 30-60 seconds per instrument; Automated: 10-20 seconds; instrument library limited (e.g., 4 instruments + camera)
instrument_exchange.single_use_instruments: Sterile, disposable instruments with RFID for usage tracking and expiration; cost driver for robotic surgery

regulatory_testing.software_validation: IEC 62304 Class C (safety-critical software); unit testing, integration testing, hazard analysis, traceability matrix
regulatory_testing.electromagnetic_compatibility: IEC 60601-1-2; immunity to OR equipment (electrosurgery, cautery); emissions limits for surgical environment
regulatory_testing.biocompatibility: ISO 10993 series for patient-contacting instruments; skin contact (Class II devices) or tissue contact (Class III)
regulatory_testing.usability_engineering: IEC 62366-1; formative and summative usability testing; use-related hazard analysis; assess learning curve, task performance, errors
regulatory_testing.clinical_studies: Demonstrate non-inferiority to standard surgical approach for primary endpoints (blood loss, complication rate, functional outcomes, oncologic margins); assess learning curve (CUSUM analysis)

usage_notes.robotic_platforms: da Vinci (Intuitive Surgical) - laparoscopic; Mako (Stryker), ROSA (Zimmer Biomet) - orthopedic; Mazor X (Medtronic) - spine
usage_notes.cost_considerations: Capital cost $0.5-2.5 million; disposable instruments $200-3000 per case; service contracts $100-200k/year
usage_notes.training_requirements: Industry proctoring, simulation-based training, credentialing typically 20-50 cases for proficiency
usage_notes.clinical_evidence: Cochrane reviews show robotic surgery reduces blood loss and hospital stay for some procedures; higher cost, longer operative time; oncologic outcomes equivalent to open/laparoscopic for prostatectomy
